Posts.Content: May 18, 2015 01:32PM Teakie88 wrote: Torridon: Please don't lose hope. I was diagnosed with many, many liver and bone mets in 2014. I was on Taxotere, Herceptin, and Perjeta, and eight months after my original treatments started, I went to NED. We have all been where you are, and if you didn't have anxiety, you wouldn't be normal. There are many, many options out there now, and many, many women/men living with Stage IV for many, many years! Take one day at a time and give yourself some space to get a handle on your situation. i believe things will look much better for you in a few days. Everyone on these boards have been a Godsend for me, and i believe I speak for everyone here, that we believe in paying it forward to the next person! Best wishes to you in your treatment plan. Ann

Posts.Content: May 28, 2015 01:12PM Teakie88 wrote: I have told only a few people, first because i'm a pretty private person to begin with, and second, I don't want that stark reaction i would be sure to get had i told them. All my family and friends knew when I had breast cancer in 2011, but very few know that it came back or that it's Stage IV. I just kind of went into seclusion so I didn't have to always explain. If I hadn't lost my hair this second go round, no one would have known about it at all. Unfortunately, I didn't know about cold caps then or I would have tried them. I don't want sympathy from anyone; I just want to go about living my life as I had always done pre-cancer. I'm one of those people before I had cancer myself that heard Stage IV and said to myself "Oh my God!", and thank God, statistics and treatments are changing that mentality for the better. So the question of telling or not telling is definitely up to the individual and how comfortable you feel about it. Ann

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2015 11:46AM Teakie88 wrote: dlb823: The story I can relate to involves pneumonia and not shingles. Got my first case of pneumonia ever in August of 2014 out of the clear blue. Hospitalized for four days and IV infusions for ten days after that. Fast forward six months later - pneumonia again in February 2015--hospitalized for four days again. I have never wanted to have the pneumonia shot because I always thought I would then probably get pneumonia from it. Two bouts of pneumonia taught me that I needed the shot, and I got it in the hospital after the second time. Thus far, no further problems of any kind. Soooo, it was also recommended that I get the shingles vaccine which I haven't had done yet, but probably most definitely will. I heard shingles are one of the worst things you can get, and they take a long, long time to go away. Ann

Posts.Content: Teakie88 wrote: I was just wondering if we could do our own poll on the possible relationship between pregnancy age and breastfeeding as it relates to breast cancer. I keep hearing now (wish I had been told this back then) that women having children at age 30 or later AND no breastfeeding run a greater risk of developing breast cancer. What better place to conduct our own research on whether or not these may truly be factors for breast cancer than right here on BCO? We can't do anything to change it now, but maybe we can help inform our daughters and friends and families with daughters about the possible link that may exist. I also had extremely dense breasts so they monitored me pretty closely, but obviously that wasn't enough. Please jump right in and: give your age for first pregnancy or more, whether you breastfed, and even whether you had dense breasts that required monitoring. Posts.Title: YEAR NINE jan125 Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2015 11:23PM Teakie88 wrote: Wow! That's interesting! I've never had anything like that happen near my port by any "creatures". The area where I live has nasty "chiggers" that embed in your skin, and I use clear fingernail polish sometimes to suffocate them and stop the constant itching. They always go in places they have no business going (around bra lines, areas around groin--you get the picture). They must really like you a lot, Sue, and want to be near you always! On a more serious note, are you wearing any kind of perfume, fabric softener, detergent, that might be attracting them in the first place? Burt's Bees makes a natural herbal insect repellent that is safe for even pets, but reviews on it say it smells bad. The plus side on it says it is nontoxic. Of course, my first thought would be that if you get attacked going to Chincoteague, then you might need to rethink that area. That's probably not an option you're going to entertain. so at this moment, I have no other real suggestions, but I sure hope someone comes along who does! Ann
Posts.Title: Bugs & ports - Yuck! sueopp Shutterbug73

Posts.Content: May 19, 2015 02:05AM Teakie88 wrote: I found that for several months after my Stage IV diagnosis that it was pretty hard for me to be optimistic about much of anything. One day, though, I got up, had my morning coffee, and it seemed like a lot of the dark clouds had cleared for me. Like passage of time had eased some of my anxiety. Since that day, I have been able to get on with my life in full force. I find that my love of yard work and other activities during the day take my mind off of cancer, and I'm definitely okay with that. I believe that the new clinical drug trials and hopefully forthcoming drugs, new views on lifestyle changes we need to make to be healthy, and more science on what makes cancer "tick" will work to help all of us as we go down this road. My best wishes to all. Ann

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2015 06:16PM Teakie88 wrote: I was just looking around at some of the different Stage IV topics that were currently going on, and I happened to run across this thread. The very first thing that struck me was that any of you 60, 70, 80, 90 had concerns about finding a thread just for you because some of you feel you don't belong, fit in, or have anything to contribute to the rest of us. All I can say is that is that if you are Stage IV, you fit in just fine with me and anyone else for that matter. I had no idea there were so many of you Stage IVers on this thread that I've never even heard from before. I just turned 60 myself, and I don't care how old I am or you are. As far as I'm concerned, your input on any of these Stage IV threads is 100% welcome. We are all one big community, with each of us having been dealt a card we wish we didn't have. Nonetheless, we all carry on one day at a time and share our thoughts, treatments, family stories, and anything else that comes to mind at the time. I would just like to say personally that I hope you ladies (and gentlemen) make it a point to join in on ANY of the Stage IV posts as we are all family here, and in my opinion, age has nothing to do with it! Hope to see some posts in other threads from you great people! Ann

Posts.Content: Teakie88 wrote: Sorry I had to relist this topic, but I couldn't stand my typo in the title of original post. I know I could have started this thread in the Complementary Medicine section, but I wanted to specifically list it in Stage IV. We know that cancer treatments cause our immune system to struggle, which is why immunotherapy is becoming such a major player in cancer treatment research now. Are there any of you who have tried or who are currently taking the Turkey Tail Mushroom extract as a supplement? I have been reading considerable information about it as it has been used in Japan for many years to boost the immune system while undergoing cancer treatments and/or maintenance. If you have consulted with your oncologist about it, what was the general consensus about taking it? Brand, dosage, side effects, and whether you feel better, worse, or no different as a result of taking it would be considered beneficial input. We have to be our own advocates, as we already know, and as a collective unit, our research may well be worth investing in on treating breast cancer. Best to all. Ann Do not go gentle into that good night (Dylan Thomas) Dx 5/19/2011, IBC, 5cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 3, 10/10 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Dx 6/6/2014, IBC, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: 8 Year Anniversary - Stage IV JeninMichigan teacher911

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2015 08:01AM Teakie88 wrote: I feel truly fortunate to have the oncologist I have as well. She is one of the most compassionate people I have ever met since I have known her starting in 2011. I think she almost lives, eats, breathes her practice. When she sees her patients like me, if everything is going pretty well that day for her, she laughs and enjoys being with all her patients. If a patient maybe has passed away or she has seen patients struggling, you can tell that it weighs on her heavily when you see her. Her staff told me that instead of picking up a novel to read for pleasure, you'll always find her reading a book on cancer treatments. She is Triple Board Certified, and I know that she has my very best interests at heart. She asked me to do a TV commercial on breast cancer that started airing in March of 2015. I felt honored that she thought enough of me as one of her patients to ask me. It is still airing on TV as we speak. She asked me a favor in helping to promote her practice and to further advance the kind of care that she provides; I, in turn, felt the least I could do was return the favor. That is the kind of mutual care and respect that we have for each other. You can't really ask for more than that. However, I'm still waiting for Hollywood to call me for a screen test! Hollywood doesn't matter as all my fellow townspeople and neighbors think I'm brave and a hero so it's a "win-win". Be assured that we are all heroes in this fight! Love to all you ladies and gents out there! Ann

Posts.Title: BLESSED EASTER TO ONE AND ALL Teakie88 sarahsusername

Posts.Content: Teakie88 wrote: My husband is having some orthodontic work done, and he had an appointment yesterday. He walked in and was greeted by all the girls in some form of pink regalia--pink tutu, pink wig, and other assorted attire. The orthodontist even had on pink slacks. He noted that many of the girls were complaining about having to wear these "reminders" on our behalf. It figures that this was the one appointment that I didn't go with him. Had I been there, I would have walked up to the girls doing the complaining and said "I would GLADLY trade places with any one of you, including wearing a tutu everyday for the rest of my life, in exchange for having breast cancer." I imagine that would have shut them up in a hurry. The sad thing is that none of them have any idea that probably at least one or more of them may end up with it down the road, regardless of mammograms or early detection, all that garbage we're always being fed about early detection saves lives. On the other side of the coin, I went into my local Post Office and on the counter was a very simple pink stand-up poster which said "October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month Find a cure!" I felt like that was more in keeping with the real agenda. I hope as time goes on that more awareness about the true nature of this beast creates a more sincere approach to breast cancer and less ignorance on the part of people who "think" they're promoting this cause the right way, but aren't. My best to all out there. Ann Do not go gentle into that good night (Dylan Thomas) Dx 5/19/2011, IBC, 5cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 3, 10/10 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Dx 6/6/2014, IBC, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2015 11:10AM Teakie88 wrote: Deanna: I have also done the research on a methionine-restricted diet. Some ladies on these boards have said they think getting bc is a "crap shoot", that no matter what you do or don't do will not influence getting it, and that's fine. Opinions are what make the world go round, and differences of opinion are what make these bc boards so interesting to read So, this is just my opinion on the subject, but I still say there is a direct correlation of some kind between bc and our lifestyles. I purchased The China Study by Thomas and T. Colin Campbell, father and son collaborators who did in-depth research on why people in China did not develop cancer over there as rampantly as countries like the U.S. did. Their findings showed that the kind of food choices the Asians made were far different from ours. For example, milk is not anything that they supposedly drink over there. It might be used to feed babies, but it is not drunk by the adults. It has also been determined that once these countries start fashioning themselves after the U.S. junk food lifestyle, rates of cancer go up over there as well. I was a good 40 lbs overweight when diagnosed, didn't eat healthy enough, didn't exercise correctly, inflammation was more than likely way out of control, ate candy and sweets (my weakness), and my list could go on and on. I have researched vegan (plant-based diets), exercise, inflammation, etc., and from everything I read, the results still seem to point to modifying our diets and lifestyles to eliminate unhealthy proteins and fats. I eat vegetarian fed chicken and turkey (Simple Truth by Krogers) when I want meat to eat, lots of vegetables and some fruits, watch how much dairy I take in. watch sugar intake and balance sugar with protein intake (protein helps offset carbs), walk 6 miles a day, do visualization practice, and take supplementation like Vitamin D. More and more research seems to show how low Vitamin D levels and cancer risk/occurrence seem to be related. So, I personally think the vegan diet is absolutely essential, but I also think other things go hand in hand with that, and I'm just trying to do everything I can to stay at NED for as long as I possibly can. It might be a year, five years, who knows. I do think if I want a fighting chance, I have to fight fire with fire by being more proactive and aggressive than the cancer itself Best to all. Ann

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2016 01:07PM Teakie88 wrote: roadchic18: I am so sorry to hear about your sister. I too had pneumonia (twice in fact)--first in August of 2014 just after start of Stage IV treatments and then again six months later in March of 2015. I was hospitalized both times (first time was the worst) with delayed treatments until the pneumonia cleared up. I was concerned about getting a pneumonia shot as I felt my immune system was already compromised, but I have not had any recurrence of pneumonia at all since then. So I hope that she will be able, if she hasn't already, to receive the shot to avoid any more problems in that area. Hopefully, they will be able to get her to a more stable condition where her appetite comes back (appetite loss is common) and she starts to feeling better. Please try to encourage her to eat even if she isn't hungry as her body needs nourishment to fight back with. Initial diagnosis and treatment of this disease can be tough on anyone, so please convey to her that so many of us have gone through what she is going through now and that it is "doable". You just have to get past the rough part and learn to adjust to the new "normal". My best wishes to her and you for renewed strength and health. Ann :

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2015 10:33AM Teakie88 wrote: I also asked my onc about how long I might be on Zometa. Their school of thought is I would probably be on it for at least 2-3 years, and then possibly I could have it stopped. Right now I take it every three weeks with my regular infusions for bone strength, and i believe that it has done wonders for me personally. The only time I ever had a side effect with it was just the first time it was given to me. I developed the "flu-like" symptoms a couple of days after the infusion, but after that first time, nothing since at all. At this point I'm not sure I would ever stop it, only stagger it out to maybe four times a year, something like that. I tend to agree with Fitztwins on how not having that drug "might" allow bone mets back in. I know it is hard to determine "yes or no" on keeping it or dropping it. Good luck in your decision. Ann

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2016 10:05AM Teakie88 wrote: Good subject. When we hear about celebrities or high-profile individuals dying of cancer or otherwise, we tend to think that they had some health guru/doctor that knew more than anyone else on how to save their life. It just goes to show that cancer hits everyone, regardless of who you are. Having said that, however, factors regarding Bowie and his lifestyle may have contributed more to his quick demise than to others with this disease. It is upsetting to hear about these deaths, but we MUST each be strong in our resolve to live each and every day, putting one foot in front of the other, and moving on. Each person is different in this disease, and what affects one does not necessarily affect the other. Be as positive as you can in your attitude, and hold on to hope! Best to all! Ann

Posts.Content: May 31, 2015 08:36AM Teakie88 wrote: Torridon: When my breast cancer turned metastatic in 2014, it certainly came as a major heartbreak to me as well. I had many, many large liver lesions as well as numerous spots on ribs. A lot of us developed liver mets, bone mets, you name it. In March of 2015 with chemo, Herceptin, Perjeta, and Zometa, I have achieved NED status. You are overwhelmed right now just as all of us were. This DOES NOT mean the end for you. Many women are living years and years with this disease, and the statistics are definitely changing for the better. Why bother? You have a 6-year old son that needs you, and you have every opportunity now to be there for him. Take some deep breaths to get your bearings on your situation, and I guarantee that given a few days or weeks, things will look up for you. All of us at BCO support each other 100%, and I KNOW YOU CAN DO THIS. Please know that all of us are here for you anytime, and we want you to do well. God bless you and best wishes for return to good health! Ann
Posts.Title: Why bother? Torridon fujiimama
